items.content_text: Use Ceremonial Actions to Prepare Yourself for Change [annahavron.com](https://www.annahavron.com/blog/use-ceremonial-actions-to-prepare-yourself-for-change) Tap into the power of ceremonial actions for making life changes.

items.content_html:
The single most helpful phrase for this parent of young adult children: “Wow, that’s (exciting / unnerving / scary / fantastic!) What do you think you’re going to do?”

Transitioning from being the kids’ Life Skills Instructor (“Wash your hands!” “Do not put the cat in the dishwasher!” “Do not put your brother in the dishwasher!“) to becoming their sounding board as they navigate their own lives, is quite an adjustment.
items.content_text:
The single most helpful phrase for this parent of young adult children: "Wow, that's (exciting / unnerving / scary / fantastic!) **What do you think you're going to do?"**

Transitioning from being the kids' Life Skills Instructor ("Wash your hands!" "Do not put the cat in the dishwasher!" "Do not put _your brother_ in the dishwasher!") to becoming their sounding board as they navigate their own lives, is quite an adjustment.

items.content_html:
Two neighbors have garden compasses, example here. With one, if you face North on the obelisk, the north is behind you. With the other, if you face North on the obelisk, the north is in front of you. I can’t figure out which way is best.

Happy Microblogvember.
items.content_text:
Two neighbors have garden compasses, example [here](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/6b/c4/74/6bc474180147e09785df08055262d1bc.png). With one,  if you face North on the obelisk, the north is behind you. With the other, if you face North on the obelisk, the north is in front of you. I can't **figure** out which way is best.

[Happy Microblogvember.](https://challenges.micro.blog/2022/10/31/microblogvember-heres-how.html)

items.content_html: Another lovely morning walk, and the green heron was here today, too. I think it’s a juvenile – lots of brown stripes and streaks. When I saw it hunting last week alongside the bank, its patterns made it nearly invisible as it stalked along the grasses. Also, enjoy some wildflowers.
items.content_text: Another lovely morning walk, and the green heron was here today, too. I think it's a juvenile -- lots of brown stripes and streaks. When I saw it hunting last week alongside the bank, its patterns made it nearly invisible as it stalked along the grasses. Also, enjoy some wildflowers.

items.content_html: So someone in my family needs a medical screening test. I asked the medical expert I live with, what the difference was between a CAT scan, a mammogram, an MRI, and a PET scan. He said, “Well, with a PET scan, you can use either a cat or a dog…”
items.content_text: So someone in my family needs a medical screening test. I asked the medical expert I live with, what the difference was between a CAT scan, a mammogram, an MRI, and a PET scan. He said, "Well, with a PET scan, you can use either a cat or a dog..."

items.content_html:
We find what we are looking for:

“There aren’t very many toys in the prehistoric archaelogical record. For a long time, archaelogists thought that was because prehistoric kids were somehow fundamentally different from modern kids. But now some scholars think that the toys are missing from the record simply because early archaeologists didn’t recognize them. Whenever they saw objects that could easily be used for children’s play, they categorized them as items used for ritual instead.”

Meg Conley, Left Behind
items.content_text:
We find what we are looking for:

>"There aren't very many toys in the prehistoric archaelogical record. For a long time, archaelogists thought that was because prehistoric kids were somehow fundamentally different from modern kids. But now some scholars think that the toys are missing from the record simply because early archaeologists didn't recognize them. Whenever they saw objects that could easily be used for children's play, they categorized them as items used for ritual instead."
>
[Meg Conley, *Left Behind*](https://www.megconley.com/left-behind/)

items.title: Rural vs Suburban: Number of Vehicles is Analogous to Number of Cats
items.content_html: My husband grew up in suburbia. I grew up in the country. As we were driving through rural Virginia, I explained to him that trucks and cars per household in the country, are like cats per household in suburbia. If you have one, that’s not enough - you can’t just have one. Two or three, that’s unremarkable. Four – eh – that can go either way. But once you have five or more vehicles in your driveway in the country and/or five or more cats at your suburban home, then people start to notice.
items.content_text: My husband grew up in suburbia. I grew up in the country. As we were driving through rural Virginia, I explained to him that trucks and cars per household in the country, are like cats per household in suburbia. If you have one, that's not enough - you can't just have one. Two or three, that's unremarkable. Four -- eh -- that can go either way. But once you have five or more vehicles in your driveway in the country and/or five or more cats at your suburban home, then people start to notice.

items.title: "Awareness, Acceptance, Exploration..." in a cell phone picture
items.content_html:
Just took a marvelous online workshop from Goodhart Photography called ‘Photography for Wellbeing.” I learned a mindfulness practice for taking photos.

This is a home-made wind bell we got at a farmstand near our favorite beach. It shattered in a windstorm years ago, but I couldn’t bear to get rid of it. (And yes, it still rings nicely.)

I feel like it just said “thanks.”
items.content_text: Just took a marvelous online workshop from [Goodhart Photography](https://goodhartphotographyva.com/) called 'Photography for Wellbeing." I learned a mindfulness practice for taking photos. This is a home-made wind bell we got at a farmstand near our favorite beach. It shattered in a windstorm years ago, but I couldn't bear to get rid of it. (And yes, it still rings nicely.) I feel like it just said "thanks."

items.title: Hey you, I mean, y'all, I mean yinz, youse guys
items.content_html: Today at Zoom Coffee Hour, we mulled over the variety of terms for the second person plural pronoun. One person, from Pennsylvania, grew up saying “yinz.” Most people around here say “y’all.” In one place I lived, it was “you guys.” My high school French teacher in Texas used to yell, “People! ‘Vous’ is ‘y’all!‘”
items.content_text: Today at Zoom Coffee Hour, we mulled over the [variety of terms for the second person plural pronoun.](https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/yall-youuns-yinz-youse-how-regional-dialects-are-fixing-standard-english) One person, from Pennsylvania, grew up saying ["yinz."](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yinz#History_and_usage) Most people around here say ["y'all."](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Y%27all) In one place I lived, it was ["you guys."](https://time.com/5688255/you-guys/) My high school French teacher in Texas used to yell, "*People!* 'Vous' is 'y'all!'"

items.title: "You like cats," she said.
items.content_html:
A statement, not a question: we were both wearing face masks with cat pictures, in the check-out line. I nodded.

“I got eleven of them, twelve if you count the one buried in the yard.” Seeing my interest, she added, “And I got two possums, three raccoons, and a couple of rats.”

She told me that one of the raccoons comes up to the sliding door because she feeds it hot dogs.

I said, “If I were a raccoon, I would show up for hot dogs.”

We nodded together about hot dogs. And then I had to pay, and go.
items.content_text:
A statement, not a question: we were both wearing face masks with cat pictures, in the check-out line.  I nodded.

"I got eleven of them, twelve if you count the one buried in the yard." Seeing my interest, she added, "And I got two possums, three raccoons, and a couple of rats." 

She told me that one of the raccoons comes up to the sliding door because she feeds it hot dogs. 

I said, "If I were a raccoon, I would show up for hot dogs."

We nodded together about hot dogs. And then I had to pay, and go.

items.title: That's a good question...
items.content_html:
KELLY: Which - I suppose, as a non-scientist, I have to ask, why? What would be the great loss to humanity if the pupfish of Devils Hole were no more?

KOLBERT: Well, I quote a biologist named Phil Pister, who was instrumental in saving the Devils Hole pupfish and other very, very endangered fish. And people would always ask him, you know, when he was devoting his life to this task, “What good are pupfish?” And his response, which I think bears repeating, was always, “What good are you?”

– from an interview on NPR
items.content_text:
> KELLY: Which - I suppose, as a non-scientist, I have to ask, why? What would be the great loss to humanity if the [pupfish of Devils Hole](https://esa.npca.org/devils-hole-pupfish/) were no more?

>KOLBERT: Well, I quote a biologist named Phil Pister, who was instrumental in saving the Devils Hole pupfish and other very, very endangered fish. And people would always ask him, you know, when he was devoting his life to this task, "What good are pupfish?" And his response, which I think bears repeating, was always, "What good are you?"

-- [from an interview on NPR](https://www.npr.org/2021/02/11/967079417/what-can-we-do-next-to-change-nature-in-order-to-save-it)

items.content_html: Started fiddling with interstitial journaling a few weeks ago. It’s surprisingly helpful. It’s like a combination emotion/distraction management tool, and a “now, where was I?” log. I’m using the Amplenote Daily Jots feature for mine. Ness Labs open-access description with Roam tips here, or scale the Wall of Medium to see Tony Stubblebine’s original article here.
items.content_text: Started fiddling with interstitial journaling a few weeks ago. It's surprisingly helpful. It's like a combination emotion/distraction management tool, and a "now, where was I?" log. I'm using the [Amplenote] (https://www.amplenote.com/) Daily Jots feature for mine. Ness Labs open-access description with Roam tips [here] (https://nesslabs.com/interstitial-journaling), or scale the Wall of Medium to see Tony Stubblebine's original article [here] (https://medium.com/better-humans/replace-your-to-do-list-with-interstitial-journaling-to-increase-productivity-4e43109d15ef).

items.content_html: This is the week to clean out the old year’s files and spreadsheets, and set up the new ones. I’m excited by the idea of organizing. I’m excited by my plans for organizing. I love thinking and planning. Actually digging into the files, however, seems suspiciously like work.
items.content_text: This is the week to clean out the old year's files and spreadsheets, and set up the new ones. I'm excited by the idea of organizing. I'm excited by my plans for organizing. I love thinking and planning. Actually digging into the files, however, seems suspiciously like work.

items.content_html: Our common image of experience is about as accurate as a still photograph of a man riding a bicycle. Project this image back into reality, and the man will fall off his bicycle. – Robert Grudin
items.content_text: >Our common image of experience is about as accurate as a still photograph of a man riding a bicycle. Project this image back into reality, and the man will fall off his bicycle. -- [Robert Grudin] (https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/277325.Time_and_the_Art_of_Living)

items.title: Year in Review, March 2020: the Catio
items.content_html: For the first time, I’m doing a yearly review using this template from Ness Labs. However, I’d like to do a photographic year in review, right here. Let’s start with Posey, who is on our screened-in porch, now known as the “catio.” This is early spring, 2020, ten days before our state issued a stay-at-home order for the pandemic.
items.content_text: For the first time, I'm doing a yearly review using this [template from Ness Labs] (https://nesslabs.com/year-in-review). However, I'd like to do a photographic year in review, right here. Let's start with Posey, who is on our screened-in porch, now known as the "catio." This is early spring, 2020, ten days before our state issued a stay-at-home order for the pandemic.

items.title: Year in Review, April 2020: We Succeed in Doubling Household Cat Census, but Fail Miserably at Sourdough
items.content_html: One month later, we adopted Beans, the nervous fellow in the box below. And yes, besides adopting a pet, I tried another pandemic cliche: baking sourdough. (My dough did not rise. It sank. I learned to make sauerkraut and pickles instead.) Beans hid under a bed for two weeks.
items.content_text: One month later, we adopted Beans, the nervous fellow in the box below. And yes, besides adopting a pet, I tried another pandemic cliche: baking sourdough. (My dough did not rise. It sank. I learned to make sauerkraut and pickles instead.) Beans hid under a bed for two weeks.

items.title: Year in Review, April 2020: Birds and Bluebells
items.content_html: Our daughter moved back home with us to attend grad school. On this day we walked at a retreat center on the Shenandoah River. Virginia bluebells in the foreground; in the background, I like to think those waterbirds with the brown heads are canvasback ducks, since it was migration season. Love this bird ID app.
items.content_text: Our daughter moved back home with us to attend grad school. On this day we walked at a retreat center on the Shenandoah River. Virginia bluebells in the foreground; in the background, I like to think those waterbirds with the brown heads are canvasback ducks, since it was migration season. Love [this bird ID app] (https://merlin.allaboutbirds.org/).

items.title: Year in Review, May 2020: Had to Cancel Spring Vacation, Garden Tries to Compensate
items.content_html: The hydrangeas decided to be all the colors this year.
items.content_text: The hydrangeas decided to be all the colors this year.

items.title: Year in Review, June 2020: Mass Mantis Transportation
items.content_html: So when we screened in the catio last summer, we neglected to notice the praying mantis egg case inside the porch. Luckily, our daughter used to work at an entomology lab. Here is my heroic family moving 300 or so mantids to the garden. We kept finding mantises for the rest of the summer; and they too got ferried to the yard.
items.content_text: So when we screened in the catio last summer, we _neglected to notice_ the [praying mantis] (https://www.almanac.com/praying-mantis-predator-garden) egg case _inside_ the porch. Luckily, our daughter used to work at an entomology lab. Here is my heroic family moving 300 or so mantids to the garden. We kept finding mantises for the rest of the summer; and they too got ferried to the yard.

items.title: Year in Review, August 2020: At the Beach, Even the Clouds Made Waves
items.content_html: Vacation in late August, to a quiet beach cottage. This was one of the strangest cloud formations I’ve ever seen. Maybe it was this phenomenon.
items.content_text: Vacation in late August, to a quiet beach cottage. This was one of the strangest cloud formations I've ever seen. Maybe it was [this phenomenon] (https://www.surfertoday.com/environment/kelvin-helmholtz-the-clouds-that-look-like-breaking-waves).

items.title: Year in Review, October 2020: Had to Cancel Family Visits, But at Least the Trees Were Beautiful
items.content_html: Gingko grove at arboretum; trees in front of our house. We had a three-hour Zoomsgiving.
items.content_text: Gingko grove at arboretum; trees in front of our house. We had a [three-hour Zoomsgiving] (https://www.syracuse.com/opinion/2020/11/editorial-cartoons-for-nov-29-2020-happy-zoomsgiving.html).

items.title: Year in Review, November 2020: Beans Tries All the Beds
items.content_html: Beans eventually came out from under the humans’ bed and tried to share a cat bed with Posey. She kicked him out, and he had to go to his own.
items.content_text: Beans eventually came out from under the humans' bed and tried to share a cat bed with Posey. She kicked him out, and he had to go to his own.

items.title: Year in Review, December 2020: Dear Family, Please Don't Blame the Post Office...
items.content_html: …when you open your Christmas boxes. In the red tote, we have Posey hunkering down to thoroughly crush the ribbons and bows. In the foreground, we have Beans activating claw mode to slice some paper. This is why we (still) can’t have nice things.
items.content_text: ...when you open your Christmas boxes. In the red tote, we have Posey hunkering down to thoroughly crush the ribbons and bows. In the foreground, we have Beans activating claw mode to slice some paper. This is why we (still) can't have nice things.
